user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_GetErrorName:
```c
int32 OS_GetErrorName(int32 error_num, os_err_name_t *err_name)
{
    int32                        return_code;
    const OS_ErrorTable_Entry_t *Error;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(err_name);

    Error = OS_GLOBAL_ERROR_NAME_TABLE;
    while (Error->Name != NULL && Error->Number != error_num)
    {
        ++Error;
    }

    if (Error->Number != error_num)
    {
        Error = OS_IMPL_ERROR_NAME_TABLE;
        while (Error->Name != NULL && Error->Number != error_num)
        {
            ++Error;
        }
    }

    if (Error->Number == error_num && Error->Name != NULL)
    {
        strncpy(*err_name, Error->Name, sizeof(*err_name) - 1);
        *err_name[sizeof(*err_name) - 1] = 0;
        return_code                      = OS_SUCCESS;
    }
    else
    {
        snprintf(*err_name, OS_ERROR_NAME_LENGTH, "OS_UNKNOWN(%d)", (int)error_num);
        return_code = OS_ERROR;
    }

    (*err_name)[OS_ERROR_NAME_LENGTH - 1] = '\0';

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_GetErrorName:
typedef char os_err_name_t[OS_ERROR_NAME_LENGTH]
...
#define OS_ERROR_NAME_LENGTH 35
...
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...

{
    int32       Number;
    const char *Name;
} OS_ErrorTable_Entry_t
...

    {OS_QUEUE_EMPTY, "OS_QUEUE_EMPTY"},
    {OS_QUEUE_FULL, "OS_QUEUE_FULL"},
    {OS_QUEUE_TIMEOUT, "OS_QUEUE_TIMEOUT"},
    {OS_QUEUE_INVALID_SIZE, "OS_QUEUE_INVALID_SIZE"},
    {OS_QUEUE_ID_ERROR, "OS_QUEUE_ID_ERROR"},
    {OS_ERR_NAME_TOO_LONG, "OS_ERR_NAME_TOO_LONG"},
    {OS_ERR_NO_FREE_IDS, "OS_ERR_NO_FREE_IDS"},
    {OS_ERR_NAME_TAKEN, "OS_ERR_NAME_TAKEN"},
    {OS_ERR_INVALID_ID, "OS_ERR_INVALID_ID"},
    {OS_ERR_NAME_NOT_FOUND, "OS_ERR_NAME_NOT_FOUND"},
    {OS_ERR_SEM_NOT_FULL, "OS_ERR_SEM_NOT_FULL"},
    {OS_ERR_INVALID_PRIORITY, "OS_ERR_INVALID_PRIORITY"},
    {OS_INVALID_SEM_VALUE, "OS_INVALID_SEM_VALUE"},
    {OS_ERR_FILE, "OS_ERR_FILE"},

    {OS_TIMER_ERR_INVALID_ARGS, "OS_TIMER_ERR_INVALID_ARGS"},
    {OS_TIMER_ERR_TIMER_ID, "OS_TIMER_ERR_TIMER_ID"},
    {OS_TIMER_ERR_UNAVAILABLE, "OS_TIMER_ERR_UNAVAILABLE"},
    {OS_TIMER_ERR_INTERNAL, "OS_TIMER_ERR_INTERNAL"},
    {OS_ERR_OBJECT_IN_USE, "OS_ERR_OBJECT_IN_USE"},
    {OS_ERR_BAD_ADDRESS, "OS_ERR_BAD_ADDRESS"},
    {OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE, "OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE"},
    {OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_TYPE, "OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_TYPE"},
    {OS_ERR_STREAM_DISCONNECTED, "OS_ERR_STREAM_DISCONNECTED"},
    {OS_ERR_OPERATION_NOT_SUPPORTED, "OS_ERR_OPERATION_NOT_SUPPORTED"},

    {OS_ERR_OUTPUT_TOO_LARGE, "OS_ERR_OUTPUT_TOO_LARGE"},

    {OS_FS_ERR_PATH_TOO_LONG, "OS_FS_ERR_PATH_TOO_LONG"},

    {OS_FS_ERR_DRIVE_NOT_CREATED, "OS_FS_ERR_DRIVE_NOT_CREATED"},
    {OS_FS_ERR_DEVICE_NOT_FREE, "OS_FS_ERR_DEVICE_NOT_FREE"},
    {OS_FS_ERR_PATH_INVALID, "OS_FS_ERR_PATH_INVALID"},

    {0, NULL} /* End of table marker */
}
...
const OS_ErrorTable_Entry_t OS_IMPL_ERROR_NAME_TABLE[] = {{0, NULL}}
...
typedef int32_t   int32
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The while-loop searches use a table terminated by an entry with Name == NULL; the loop condition tests Error->Name != NULL first (short-circuit), so those iterations do not read past the table terminator and need no further investigation. The OS_CHECK_POINTER(err_name) macro verifies the pointer is non-NULL before use. The error tables are statically sized and terminated with {0, NULL}, so scanning them as done is safe. sizeof(*err_name) yields the full array size (OS_ERROR_NAME_LENGTH) due to the typedef, so the calculated sizes used in calls are consistent with the defined buffer length. The listed fragments are the only places where string-copy/formatting and explicit byte writes to the error-name buffer occur and therefore must be inspected for potential out-of-bounds or incorrect pointer/indexing behavior; other code in the function does not perform string buffer accesses and thus does not need investigation for Rule 21.17.
